title: Program Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Aug 2021
Interview Descriptions:
I was interviewing for a position at Barrett Honors College, and this was easily the most unprofessional interview experience I have ever had -- which was disappointing, as I really admired Barrett beforehand.

After reviewing my resume, I was called by a member of the team to set up a first round zoom interview. This interview was about 35 minutes long, and involved around 7-8 of the team members at Barrett. The interview went very well -- all of the interviewers were very professional and seemed honestly interested in finding out more about me and my qualifications. 

I was called the next day and invited to participate in a second interview, this time with the Dean and Assistant Dean. This interview also went extremely well, and even ended with the Dean and I brainstorming ideas for new programs we could implement. I was told in this interview that the final decision was between myself and one other candidate, and that I would be hearing back very soon, since they were looking to hire ASAP. 

After this second round interview, I immediately sent a "thank you" email within 24 hours, and waited to hear back. And then continued to wait. After a little over a week, I sent a follow up email to my primary contact in the recruiting process -- and never heard back. She never even acknowledged receiving either of my emails, and I eventually resigned myself to the fact that I had been permanently ghosted by Barrett -- after the decision had come down to only two candidates!

After over a MONTH, I received an AUTOMATED email saying that they had decided to go a different direction. I have received better treatment after a phone screening flop. I thought Barrett seemed like a great place to work, but this shows that it likely isn't the great culture they claim. Barrett needs to work on their ability to professionally reject a candidate in a timely manner. This behavior is unprofessional and would not be accepted by candidates, and should not be acceptable from employers.
Interview Questions: How are honors students unique, and how would this impact the programs you would implement for them?

title: Communications Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University
Interview Descriptions:
My experience interviewing with ASU began positively, but ended on an extremely negative note. This account will surely be longer than others to hopefully bring light to their “organized interview practices”:

I had two amazing interviews with a “panel” of interviewers, which consisted of one phone interview and one video conference. The questions I was asked mainly focused on my experience, and emphasized how I’d preform in certain situations. I was not given any account from the interviewers during either interview regarding what, exactly, I’d be managing if hired for this role— however, this didn’t bother me as much as I now realize it should have. From the beginning, I was clear and upfront that I was a candidate that was relocating to the area from across the country, and the team seemed to be receptive of this and even excited for me. Up until my following unpleasant experience, I sincerely loved the team and thought we’d work well together. 

The part where this turned negative was the fact that AFTER these two interviews, I was seen to be “disqualified” via my light quantifiable experience. I mean, my resume details my “years of experience” in full for the corporate positions I have previously worked, but I was asked by a director/coordinator of the department via email to send over an account of the “exact amount of hours and months” and “a summary of tasks completed” for my collegiate extracurricular roles in an attempt to ensure qualification for the “exact year requirement needed for the role per HR requirements”. Bonus: I was also asked to specify whether these roles- dubbed “volunteer roles” (ex: RA and sorority positions) had been “paid/unpaid”. I’d give a bit of leeway for a corporate office to mix up extra curriculars as potential ‘paid/unpaid’ positions, but this interview in question was for a role at a collegiate organization...which makes you wonder, “really?” One would hope that the "panel" had reviewed my credentials prior to the initial interview as my experience was said to be "great” for the role, but since I was later found to be a “year short” I was asked to give a detailed account of my extra curricular roles and their descriptions/tasks to try to “make up for the gap”. I found this practice odd and highly disorganized, but I complied as best I could. 

These odd and somewhat insulting questions regarding my extra curricular activities “volunteer roles” were asked leading up to and ON my moving day via email from the director of the department. Throughout the process, it almost seemed as though jumping on a quick call to give this additional information was frowned upon so I was subjected to untimely and intrusive “back and forth” email chains that stretched this process out to the point (almost a month after the first interview) where I was unable to answer “ASAP” because I was literally in the middle of moving. I figured I’d answer this “moving day email” as soon as I had reached my destination  just in case there were any additional arbitrary “follow up” back and forth emails to follow that I needed to respond to “ASAP”.  

After 3 days of driving, I tried to respond as best as I could to the email sent to me on my moving day 1 business day earlier. In an attempt to set needed boundaries with this director, I also politely added that “if there were any other questions that needed to be answered ASAP on my part to move this process forward to please CALL ME” (as my wifi had not be set up yet and I needed time to unpack after my move.) This, I felt, implied that I (understandably) could not be glued to my email in order to focus on wrapping up my move to the area. 

After this final reply politely asking for all future ASAP questions or communications to be directed to a call, my prior 3.5 weeks worth of effort were thrown out the window.  These weeks featured two interviews, an odd “email only” reference check, and a  very strange previously detailed back and forth of untimely and seemingly intrusive “final follow up questions” via email. I was then sent a generic rejection email from someone I had not even built rapport with in the panel of interviewers I had spoken with previously. This tactic felt extremely disingenuous and unappreciative of the time I had spent as an applicant who had shown "exactly what they were looking for."

In conclusion: My unpleasant experience interviewing with ASU seems to follow the negative experience of others who have shared a similar odd “cop out” is received late in the interview process- after everything seems to be at a stopping point. This “cop out” I personally experienced made the department I interviewed with seem extremely disorganized and unsure of what their hiring priorities/strategies were. Setting necessary communication boundaries is not applauded nor appreciated, I suppose (how ironic), when interviewing with ASU which makes me feel like I dodged a bullet in terms of actually working for this disorganized organization.
Interview Questions: Describe a way you created a new “communication tactic” in your organization

title: Enrollment Coach-Ed Plus Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Sept 2019
Interview Descriptions:
I had an initial phone interview, followed by an in-person interview at the call center in Tempe at The University Center. The in-person interview was a panel formate with the candidate in the middle. You have to pay for parking at a meter. I think about 8 people were there and a couple took turns asking a few questions. 

This position was so perfect for me and I did really well in the process. Throughout this process, salary was not mentioned! 

I received a call shortly after informing me that I am on  "conditional offer"- meaning if I pass the background check, in addition salary was mentioned. I didn't take this as an actual offer so I did not negotiate salary. I assumed this was just a heads up because that is how the person made it seem. I set up an appointment for fingerprinting, I made a whole spreadsheet of how I would pay off my debt, I was really excited. a Few days later I received an offer via email- this I took as an actual offer. Imagine how excited I was to finally start my career with a Job that I knew I would love. 
I kindly emailed the HR lady back asking if a little bit of a higher salary was possible. I expected them to say no but I didn't want to regret not asking later.

The next day I received a voicemail from the hiring manager telling me my offer was rescinded!!! My heart was shattered and I frantically tried contacting them to apologize for whatever I had done. I emailed the hiring manager and she called me. I explained that I had been taught to negotiate salary and I apologize if it was off putting. I pleaded with her not to withdraw my offer but she was very very cold. I realized I was just a number to her. 

She actually told me, " we have a pool of great candidates and we already moved on." Which literally made me feel worthless. It was a nice way of telling me, "you don't actually matter to us." I was also surprised by how fast they moved on, this whole interaction happened in a matter of hours. She added that she didn't just rescind the offer because I negotiated, but because I was "hard to get in contact with." 
I had 2 phone calls from the school after interviews and both I immediately called back, which lead me to believe she was just justifying the unreasonable withdraw.  
I cried for days after! I couldn't believe how disposable I was to them.
Interview Questions: Tell us about a time when you made a mistake and how you handled it.

title: Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Aug 2018
Interview Descriptions:
I was quite shocked to read such positive interview reviews for ASU.  My experience was frustrating.  I work in a specialty field, and at this point, I'm pretty well qualified in my specialty.   I have a lot of corporate experience under my belt, but I also have prior experience in higher education.  I feel I was very sincere when I told my group of interviewers that I genuinely wanted to work in higher education again.  I don't know how much clearer/nicer I could have been about that!  It's the truth - I'm tired of the nonsense that goes on in the corporate world! 
As it turns out, higher education (at least at ASU) is really just as "corporate" as the corporate world!  It's awfully hypocritical of the hiring manager, who I know for a fact has prior "corporate" experience, to turn around and basically tell me that I'm too qualified for the job I applied to.  It's safe for me to assume that the hiring manager is "overqualified" for their own role given their past corporate experience.  If I was so over-qualified, why even bring me in to interview?  My qualifications are clearly outlined on my resume.  If this is just a matter of me not being "liked" or not being seen as a fit, I would have preferred to receive no response at all.  I feel this whole "over-qualified" nonsense was nothing more than a hypocritical cop-out.  Of course, this was my experience with ONE department.  Maybe I'd have a better experience with another one, but I'd go into it with caution.
Interview Questions: Describe a time when you worked with a difficult client/customer.

title: Administrative Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Arizona State University
Interview Descriptions:
Applied online. Took them about 4+ months to call me, but I now work there and see that is common.

Phone interview with several members of team. They usually ask about 4 or 5 situational questions. If you are familiar with STAR format, that is the system they follow. A week later I was called back for an in-person interview.

In person interview took place on campus. Panel included my potential supervisor, a member of the team, a person who was doing a job similar to the one I was interviewing for, and another member of the department I was interviewing with. Was called 2 weeks later with an offer. Pay was bottom of the range and firm - no negotiating possible. I accepted because I really wanted to work for ASU and haven't regretted it.

Random Tips: 
I have since been on several hiring committees at ASU and the experience outlined above is commonly how things work. The hiring managers like to have a mixture of individuals on the interview panels to get a more well-rounded opinion of the candidate and they will include people at all levels, not just manager-types. This being an organization that focuses heavily on student engagement and the ability to work with diverse populations, the focus is generally on how well-liked you will be and how easily you connect with people from various backgrounds/job levels. The questions will follow a STAR format and they will be grading you based on how well your response shows job-area knowledge and how your experience relates to the position. The questions themselves are not hard to answer and are very basic. What I have found through working with various committees is that they are mostly looking for someone who can easily do the job with little training, will be well-liked by both students and staff (i.e. have a positive attitude, show initiative, show that you are really excited to work with students and be part of a college environment..they really like positive, upbeat people and will refer constantly to the "energy" a person put forth in the interview) and has as much experience as possible. This is not the type of place, culturally, where they are looking to train someone who has never done the job...experience is key. Even if your experience is just as a student worker or through an internship, you should focus on how that experience will translate well into the position you're interviewing for. Before you go to the interview, really read the job description and think about ways that your experience relates to what they are looking for. They personally screen the resumes and will be looking for well-written cover letters that connect experience to the position they're hiring for. It's a very casual workplace and it's okay to show some personality but we have definitely had people who go overboard. Show that you are flexible, fun and able to get the job done. Remember that it is all about the students and helping them stay engaged and supported.
Interview Questions: Explain a time in a previous/current position that a process changed with very little notice and how you adapted to that change?

Interview Descriptions: The professor will talk with you and ask you some question about the research.  Usually it will last for 1 hour. When you answer the question, you can ask questions.
Interview Questions: What's the mechanism of LED

title: Community Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Feb 2016
Interview Descriptions: Entirely behavioral. Two current CA's and the CD (community director) interview you. They take turns asking questions. Your answers are rated on a 1-5 scale, I think. 5 means you'd hire based off that answer and 1 means you would absolutely not.
Interview Questions: Give an example of a time you showed leadership qualities

title: Director of IT Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Phoenix, AZ) in Feb 2016
Interview Descriptions: I was asked questions straight from the job description. There was a three member panel and they took turns asking questions. I was never given the opportunity to interview with the person I would have been reporting to.
Interview Questions: What is open access?

title: Student Worker IV Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Arizona State University
Interview Descriptions: It was around 45 minutes of length and we discussed about my academic projects and interest areas. The Interviewers asked about Computer Science basic concepts and my work experience in the industry.
Interview Questions: How does any Web Application work?

title: Assistant Professor of History Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ)
Interview Descriptions: I lived in Arizona at the time and I drove to the University for the interview. They did not seem particularly interested in filling this position.  I was not take to lunch or dinner,  The Dean was blunt and not terribly friendly. He offered $18,000 as starting salary which was not adequate for 1980, the offer could not be negotiated he insisted,  The next hire was also for assistant prof in Black Studies (one year later).  She received $22,000 offer,  I was left behind salary structure throughout the whole time I was at the university.
Interview Questions: committee quizzed on my publications research interests. They were concerned bout my teaching philosophy.  They asked me what courses I had taught at my previous faculty position.

title: Administrative Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Glendale, AZ)
Interview Descriptions: Group interview with director and other staff members.  Each member asked various questions.  They were standard questions:  tell about yourself and experience, where do you see yourself in 5 years etc.  The panel was friendly and relaxed.  Just be prepared to talk about your previous experience and how it relates to the position you are applying for.
Interview Questions: Experience as Administrative Assistant

title: Teacher Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Phoenix, AZ)
Interview Descriptions: I had to write a letter to parents and family for my classroom, give a demonstration lesson in front of middle school students, then sit in a panel interview with at least 5 administrators.
Interview Questions: What does personalized instruction mean to you?

title: Student Worker IV Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1+ week. I interviewed at Arizona State University in Jan 2016
Interview Descriptions: Applied Online was offered an interview. Proceeded with the interview. Professional interview but was in no way difficult. Asked for resume. Asked question about resume. Gave interview slots availability. Explained job expectations. Expected questions about position. Short interview maybe 20 - 30 mins. Very friendly.
Interview Questions: Examples of leadership experience, and growth in leadership development.

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Jan 2016
Interview Descriptions: i applied online. then i received several questions to fill out with a one and half week deadline. after that there was a phone interview. the following week there was an in-person interview, which included questions, a chance to meet with the research team as well as an excel test. the interview process was easy and straightforward. interviewers asked questions from a list and took notes on my answers.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work in research?

title: Graduate Services Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Jan 2016
Interview Descriptions:
I was a good interview. It had one coding challenge in which we needed to develop an Android application to develop some features of autograding student's copies by taking their pictures.
We were given references to Tesseract OCR library. But Tesseract isn't good to recognize the handwritten characters. It can recognize printed text. That's the challenge they wanted to test how we can tackle.
Interview Questions: Develop a code to detect the handwritten Java code of the student.

title: Student Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Jan 2016
Interview Descriptions: Standard Interview: Talked with two managers for less than an hour. They asked questions off a sheet they had, mostly behavioral based inquiries. Asked me to walk them through my resume and pervious experience.
Interview Questions: How has your previous experience prepared you for this position?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Jan 2016
Interview Descriptions: Directed contacted the professor to first work at volunteer which then progressed to a paid part-time job. The process was easy, I saw an ad in the school digest for the particular lab position. The professor was great and explained the details of the position which changed through my years of working there.
Interview Questions: What classes are you taking?

title: Admissions and Financial Aid Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Dec 2015
Interview Descriptions:
A month after I applied, I was contacted by a secretary to arrange a phone interview with four individuals, some of whom would be my peers, and one of whom would be my direct supervisor. It was perfunctory and lasted 15 minutes or so.

Four days later, I was contacted by the secretary again to schedule an in-person presentation and interview with the same people. I was asked to present on the financial aid process. The interview was somewhat formal. 

Following this, I was contacted to come in for a very last-minute final interview with my future supervisor's supervisor. This interview seemed perfunctory and was very assumptive. The interviewer was not able to provide detailed salary and benefits information, so I requested that I be contacted with this information.

A holiday interrupted the hiring process, but in early January I was contacted by my future supervisor by phone. She offered me the job, which I accepted after receiving the information I had requested.
Interview Questions: Describe a time you went above and beyond to solve a difficult situation in admissions.

title: Marketing Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University in Nov 2015
Interview Descriptions: Very friendly, Seemed a little unorganized, Casual setting within the office, one on one review with the director of the complex, After the interview I had to call them to follow up and then got the job.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work here?

title: Instructional Designer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Arizona State University
Interview Descriptions: Applied online and was contacted about 2.5 weeks later for an phone nterview.  I spoke with two people, the direct supervisor for the position and one person from upper management for the entire department.  They said they would be contacting people during the following week for in-person interviews. I didn't hear anything else until someone from HR reached out saying I was not selected.
Interview Questions: 15 minutes long.  They gave background about the department and immediate goals for the position.  They asked 4 questions about my interest in the position and short terms goals, least favorite thing about the work, what my biggest impact has been, and what I would accept for salary.  Then I was able to ask a few questions.

title: Laboratory Aide Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 days. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Oct 2015
Interview Descriptions: Fast paced hiring process, you should demonstrate skills to your potential supervisor to get hired. A little paper work was required which was not a problem at all. Nothing so special about the interview, as i mentioned just make contacts with the supervisor and you will get the job.
Interview Questions: why are fit for the job?

title: Desk Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University
Interview Descriptions: The highering process was long winded, I applied in novemenber and finally landed the job the last week of october. There was only one major interview where you were asked things such as "how would you handle these specific situations". What do you think the role of a desk assistant is. Do you think its fair for desk assistants to be paid minimum wage.
Interview Questions: How would you handle someone coming in asking to talk to your community director?

title: Proctor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Phoenix, AZ) in Sept 2015
Interview Descriptions: First I received an  email asking for my availability to setup a one-on-one interview. It was a normal  interview with the Supervisor and an assistant. The interview went on only for like 30 minutes. The assistant was taking notes throughout the interview. In the end I was told that they would get back to me within a week, which they did.
Interview Questions: Previous experience or interactions with disabled/challenged people.

title: Admissions Representative Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Sept 2015
Interview Descriptions: You interview with a panel of 5 - 10 people and are asked a series of questions; what are your strengths and weaknesses, what do you enjoy doing off hours.
Interview Questions: What are your strengths?

title: Instructional Designer At EdPlus Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Phoenix, AZ) in Sept 2015
Interview Descriptions: Submitted materials through a very cumbersome and dated applicant-tracking system. An admin contacted me to set up a 15 min. phone screen, which I did the following week with a panel of three people who actually worked at EdPlus (no recruiter step, which caught me off guard). It was an awkwardly short amount of time to try interact with three people via phone, not nearly enough time to answer questions fully or ask any questions I had. Panel didn't seem particularly interested in me or excited about the work they were doing, which was really disappointing after reading about EdPlus and all the amazing work they do (the person leading the interview had this sort of bored, removed tone in his voice as he very vaguely described the work). Since employers always treat you the best while they are trying to hire you, it made me question how great the work culture would be. I also left the interview not at all inspired about the work or convinced it would be an exciting, innovative place to work.
Interview Questions: Why this job?

title: Language Helper Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Sept 2015
Interview Descriptions: just basic questions about my personality and schedule. I needed to be aware of other cultures and understand how to interact with non native English speakers. Having a background in traveling or dealing with international students is a plus. Its also very important to have an open schedule. you will need to be able to schedule hours randomly throughout the week for conversation groups/activities.
Interview Questions: Describe some international experiences you have had?

title: Fitness Weight Room Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Mesa, AZ) in Sept 2015
Interview Descriptions: I was asked on why I like fitness, and why I applied for it. Also was asked if I knew how to perform lifts and how to spot someone. Also later on in the interview I had to demonstrate how to spot someone who is benching and squatting, and how to set up the station for those lifts.
Interview Questions: What is your favorite food?

title: Student Marketing Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Mesa, AZ) in Sept 2015
Interview Descriptions: It was a very short interview. I felt that they were desperate for help the position itself was merely for students so it was not tightly regulated. And I feel they felt the position could be filled by any student. Fortunately for them I was not any student.
Interview Questions: How will you improve ASU's reputation

title: Management Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 days. I interviewed at Arizona State University
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was rather simplistic and not difficult to engage in. As long as you have your resume memorized, have some what of a personality, express interest in caring for others, and hold a conversation for longer that 5 minutes, you are pretty much set.
Interview Questions: Describe a time in the past where you provided guidance to others.

title: Systems Support Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Aug 2015
Interview Descriptions: This was a promotional interview. The questions were a lot like the interview I had to get the job. Every interviewer has several sheets of paper that have questions on it and they take turns asking the questions. Be prepared to spend 50-60 minutes.
Interview Questions: When was a time you had a very difficult customer, what happened and what was the outcome?

title: Personal Trainer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Phoenix, AZ) in Aug 2015
Interview Descriptions: A three stage process geared towards culture fit as well as skills assessment to find quality personal training applicants. The process is slightly lengthy due to the three phases of the screening.
Interview Questions: What are the energy systems of the body?

title: Instructor Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 6 months. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Phoenix, AZ) in Aug 2015
Interview Descriptions: I submitted my resume; We had a telephone interview. I was accepted as an instructor. At first I was going to teach the autumn course; then they decided to have me teach in spring... so there was a bit of delay in our next correspondence. I needed to send in paperwork; past degree papers. We discussed the course; time passed. This next semester came up; I followed up with the Master Course Training; initiated conversation again; became contracted; and will begin teaching in a few weeks.
Interview Questions: They asked obviously about my teaching experience; and my experience in communications on sustainable development.

title: Student Worker Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Phoenix, AZ) in Aug 2015
Interview Descriptions: Received a call asking to schedule an interview and confirm information on the resume. Attended the interview where two people asked me situational questions and recorded my responses. Received a call three days later after the background check was completed offering me the position.
Interview Questions: How do you manage your time with multiple projects going?

title: Student Success Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University (New York, NY) in Jul 2015
Interview Descriptions: Communication is all via email and there was less than 24 hours to prepare. Interview was about 30 minutes, and was fairly scripted. No discussion about salary, benefits, or specific expectations.
Interview Questions: Many questions centered on examples of past successes (quantifiable).

title: Ticket Sales Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Jul 2015
Interview Descriptions: Group interview. Very easy. questions about what sales experience you have. Then you wentt round and did some icebreakers. Mostly seemed like a chance to review your voice and interactions.
Interview Questions: What is leaving money on the table?

title: Educational Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Jul 2015
Interview Descriptions: They emailed me politely to arrange the interview. Two people interviewed me. They talked very nicely to me, and that gave me a big relief. They asked me questions regarding what I have written on the resume. I honestly answered them with details and smile. A practical question that they asked me was "what would you do as a teacher, if you see a student playing around at the back of the classroom?" I answered, I would go up to him and say "You seem like having a lot of fun here. Do you mind sharing it with the rest of the class?" They laughed. And I think that is how I got this job.
Interview Questions: Could you tell us about what you did in the elementary school that you volunteered in?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Arizona State University
Interview Descriptions: It is a typical hiring process in academia. You are invited for a talk followed by one-to-one meetings with senior faculties and a tour of some facilities and labs. You need to talk about your background, research interest, what research direction you want to take in the next few years and how you plan to obtain funding to support your research.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Assistant Professor Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Arizona State University
Interview Descriptions: It is a typical hiring process in academia. You are invited for a talk followed by one-to-one meetings with senior faculties and a tour of some facilities and labs. You need to talk about your background, research interest, what research direction you want to take in the next few years and how you plan to obtain funding to support your research.
Interview Questions: my future plans

title: Systems Support Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Jun 2015
Interview Descriptions:
Easy online application. Waited for about 3 weeks before getting a call for an interview. Interview was panel of 3 managers; round-robin style questions. Most of the interview was focused on specific software to the position. A second portion of the interview was focused on customer service questions especially how to deal with upset customers.
About 2 weeks after the interview, I was called with an offer for the position.
Interview Questions:
Tell us about your current/last position. 
From a customer service point of view
From a technical support point of view

title: Service Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 1+ week. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Jun 2015
Interview Descriptions: It was sort of an HR interview. The questions were basically about personality. They wanted to hire people who can work in a team environment. Skills required were MS office and handle international students.
Interview Questions: The questions were mainly related to leadership skills and team wok.

title: Safety Escort Service Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Jun 2015
Interview Descriptions: Sat down in an office one on one and was asked a series of questions regarding what I would do in a given situation and personality traits. Laid back but professional.
Interview Questions: How would I act with a patron in the vehicle.

title: Graphic Design Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Mesa, AZ) in Jun 2015
Interview Descriptions:
I applied for this position online after reading the job description and finding it was very similar in job duties to my position at the time, but paid significantly more and had more opportunities for advancement.

I put in my resume the day before and was surprised to hear back the next day. All of the other jobs I'd applied to at ASU over the months before had taken 3-4 weeks to hear anything back from. After having applied to (6) other positions, this is the first I received a call back on, even though I was qualified (or overly qualified) for every position.

In the interview, I was contacted by the director of the department and his secretary who asked me a series of questions. I prepared for the interview for the entire week before and heavily researched the department and its goals, but upon starting the interview, it became very apparent that the listed job description was FAR from what they actually wanted. The position was actually for a web development position, of which at the time, I had no major experience in.

I feel as though I handled the questions adequately, but I told the director straight up that my strong suit wasn't web development and I'd applied to the position because the job description said it was for a graphic design position for print and some web. He told me the description used was from a template ASU uses for their positions and he didn't have time to edit it.

In other words, the interview was a complete waste of my time because the director was too busy to put in any work to put an accurate job description in the listing. VERY disappointed - and this actually happened to me TWO more times in the coming months. I've since given up on applying to positions at ASU because their job listings are misleading and interviewers unprofessional. I'd been dreaming of working for the institution I had graduated with a degree from for years, but the whole process really rubbed me the wrong way.
Interview Questions: We see you're good at graphic design and have been working in the print industry for years, how comfortable are you with building websites? The job is about 90% web and 10% print and being able to quickly put up pages within 24 hours of meeting with clients is a large focus of the job.

title: Office Supervisor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Jun 2015
Interview Descriptions: Applied for position online.  Applications were reviewed by immediate supervisor for best qualified candidates; candidates were pre-screen and/or interviewed via telephone call with two center staff member one of which was the immediate supervisor for the position and the other the center director.  After the best candidates were identified from the phone screening, in person interviews were scheduled with co-worker and supervisor.  There were approximately 10 questions presented.  Candidate had opportunity to answer questions and to also ask questions; next process was to be called back for a 2nd interview with the center director; Center director asked question regarding background experience and reason for wanted toworkat ASU and in specific center.
Interview Questions: Presented scenarios regarding distraught student and asked how I would handle the situation.

title: Data Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in May 2015
Interview Descriptions: It was a phone interview with three ASU employers. They were very friendly. They asked two or three questions each over the course of about 20 minutes. Afterwards they made time available to me task my own questions of them and answered them completely.
Interview Questions: They asked about my background as it would apply to they job for which I was interviewing

title: Student Worker Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Arizona State University
Interview Descriptions: I sent in my application online and they got back to me rather quickly. I had an interview set up only a few days later. Two different people interview me as well, but it went rather quickly, they mainly focused on what was on my resume and a few regular questions one would expect from an interview. They got back to me about 3 days later offering me the job.
Interview Questions: How do you manage your time between school and work?

title: Senator Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Apr 2015
Interview Descriptions: Got approached by USG representatives for a Senator position for the Ira A Fulton Schools of Engineering due to my ties and relationships with the undergraduate student government. I accepted to take the interview with the Senate President and got hired on the spot
Interview Questions: What was the biggest Mountain before Mount Everest was discovered?

title: Grad Student Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Arizona State University
Interview Descriptions: It was online and through mail. It was simple, primary requirements include a standardized test, letter of recommendation, submission of GPA and transcripts. It was very easy for my masters program. The business school provides alot of resources and can be very helpful.
Interview Questions: What is your GPA?

title: PhD Applications Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Arizona State University
Interview Descriptions: There are no interviews for a PhD position. You would just have to apply online and email faculty of your interest. Later if you get admitted then you can email them again letting them know that you have made it.
Interview Questions: PhD application

title: Student Worker I Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Arizona State University
Interview Descriptions: For such a low level job, I was interviewed by a panel of the three upper management of my department. Interesting approach as I was a full time student simply looking for part time work. But obviously with student worker positions they generally receive an overabundance of applications to the point that they gladly weed out dozens of applicants through any reasonable criteria.
Interview Questions: They ask and expect to know the department mission statement, and how you will contribute to that.

title: Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Mar 2015
Interview Descriptions: First there was a phone screening. Then there was an in-person interview with multiple parts. There was an interview with the hiring committee, an open forum with the whole department and important campus partners, a presentation, another interview with the management team, and a tour of campus.
Interview Questions: What is your supervisory style?

title: Computer Science Tutor (Student Worker III) Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Mar 2015
Interview Descriptions:
The interview consists of a set of behavioral questions followed by a written test on relevant subjects. 

The behavioral questions are to test how you will handle students that have procrastinated the assignment or are indignant that they are unable to learn a concept. The behavioral qualities sought for this position are patience, creativity, and communication. 

The written test is relatively and focuses on specific concepts rather than key concepts from courses such as CSE110, CSE120, CSE205, CSE230, or CSE240. There are about 5 to 6 questions and they are relatively easy if you scored good marks in these courses.
Interview Questions: What would you say to a student who has an assignment due imminently and insists on you giving them the solution?

title: Graduate Student Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Feb 2015
Interview Descriptions: There was a problem that was given earlier for which I needed to write a program and submit the solution before the interview. Then there was a 1 hour interview in which we discussed the solution to  the problem provided earlier, mast experiences and how I could use them to solve future problems of the nature expected at the job.
Interview Questions: Here we discussed the solution to the problem and looked over the code I had written and about my past experiences and the tasks to expect as part of this job and how we may go about solving them.

title: Field Service Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Feb 2015
Interview Descriptions: its quite simple and is completed in 1 week. Share your interview experience insights with job seekers so that they can know what to expect from the hiring process. Share your interview experience insights with job seekers so that they can know what to expect from the hiring process
Interview Questions: why this position

title: Graduate Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Feb 2015
Interview Descriptions: 1 day of interview with 4 faculty members related to your field of research. Mostly just hanging out with the professors and talking about what you like to do, what you liked about what you did and research related stuff. Interviewers usually have 30 minutes each. All of my interviewers were nice
Interview Questions: Questions mostly pertained to my past research experience and future aspirations

title: Graduate Teaching Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Phoenix, AZ) in Feb 2015
Interview Descriptions: Email interview. I submitted my application package 4 months ahead of the deadline. However, due to limited funding, there was no guarantee whether I would be accepted. After a long waiting, I finally received their offer. My professor texted my about the decision.

title: Student Office Assistant Interview

Interview Descriptions: I applied online through my.asu career tab. Got a phone call to do on campus interview after 1 week of applying. There were 4 interviewers. Got the offer after 1 week. I had to do background check as well after I got the offer before I could start working.

title: Project Management Assistant Interview

Interview Descriptions: Very chilled out interview, basic questions on your previous experience. Overall it was a very calm interview and mainly they focus on the skills you have. try to answers as real as possible, mainly what you have already worked on. all questions will be straight forward.

title: Research Assistant Interview

Interview Descriptions: It was a simple process. I have email my professor about my interest and he has invited me to talk one on one, then he has accepted to take me into his team.

Interview Descriptions: Submit an online application and indicate the subjects you are good at, year in school and available time schedule. title: Ph D Graduate Student Interview

Interview Questions: What makes a Ph. D student successful?

What was your previous experience?
What was your skills?
What are your strengths and weaknesses?
How does your skill set apply to this job?

Interview Descriptions: I was asked to submit an application, resume, and cover little through their online system. Once received, my references were contacted via email and requested to answer a very basic questionnaire. I was offered the position within 1 week of applying.

title: Administrative Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University
Interview Descriptions: One phone contact to set up interview. Two in-person interviews. One phone discussion to accept offer/negotiate salary. The interview process was quite simple really. I only had to interview with one person for the first interview, and for the second I spoke directly to the manager/supervisor who I would be working directly with.
Interview Questions: I was asked to tell them what I knew about [very difficult] research area that the office worked in. My job would ultimately have very little (if anything at all) to do with that research subject.

title: Community Mentor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Arizona State University
Interview Descriptions: The hiring process made me feel like the university is what it is known for, a giant party. Nobody knew what they were doing, they still don't. It's all just a big joke. The more you used the word "community" in your interview, the more likely you are to get the job. It's like they keep count, and if you said it the most you're the winner of this incredibly sucky job.
Interview Questions: Why do you want this job? We all want it for the free room and board, but we can't say that. Use community a hundred times in one sentence and they'll think you're a genius!

title: Assistant Professor Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University
Interview Descriptions: Typical academic interview process - teaching and research presentations to graduate students and faculty and then panel interviews with hiring committee that sometimes includes out of department member(s). Some programs invite students to participate. Meetings with college leaders (assist / assoc dean). Be clear if you want to meet with specific program or center staff or faculty, realtor, etc. Interview process is 1.5 days. Very full during that time. Office hours by job candidates are silly and almost never used by anyone to come meet a candidate so don't be disappointed.
Interview Questions: How will you help with the vision of the New American University?

title: Computer Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Dec 2014
Interview Descriptions: Applied on college website. Got a mail asking me set up a interview. On the day, I was asked to explain about my self and my past experience w.r.t job. Then another HR round followed by technical
Interview Questions: everything on your resume. I was asked to explain everything thats on my resume. Then asked me to explain about how i use jquery, ajax and other scripting work. Then some other questions on database stuff,

title: Subject Area Tutor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Dec 2014
Interview Descriptions: One on one with the supervisor of the tutoring center. Was inside  the supervisor's office to it was laid back yet still professional. I never felt uncomfortable or attacked during the interview, and the supervisor was friendly to me the whole time. Unfortunately setting up the interview and getting the correct time and date took a while because of slow email responses, but once in it was a breeze.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work here?

title: Tutor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Nov 2014
Interview Descriptions: Interview consisted of an online application and in-person interview. The online application was standard compared to the rest of the part-time job opportunities available at ASU but with the additional requirement of describing what grades were achieved in certain subjects. During the interview there were a few behavioural questions mixed with antiquated questions regarding strengths/weaknesses and funny icebreaker questions. An offer was made within 2 weeks and the entire experience was a devilish good time.
Interview Questions: Tell me about a time when you had a difficult team member

title: Chinese Teaching Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University
Interview Descriptions: I have a referral, and submitted the resume online. After about 3 weeks I got an email about a on-site interview. The questions are very basic. Interview took about 20 minutes. After one on-site interview, I got the offer.
Interview Questions: The interviewer who is also my supervisor now is very nice, and the questions are based on resume and self introduction.

title: Student Office Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Oct 2014
Interview Descriptions: Met with the manager and was hired on the spot in 10 minutes. There was a phone call with the HR manager a few days before the interview just to see if I was still interested in the position. The interview was held in the office I would be working. Manager seemed unorganized, cluttered, and the  desk was messy. There did not seem to be any attempt to be professional.
Interview Questions:
What is your availability?
When can you start?

title: Deskside Support Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Phoenix, AZ) in Oct 2014
Interview Descriptions: After submitting my resume, I did not get any call for little over 2 months. Once I got the call, the process literally took 2 weeks. I worked in their UTO department for 8 month until I graduated. I worked in the Tech Studio. I was a student worker, hence there wasn't any benefits or perks. Interview was an hour tops, and it was easy.
Interview Questions: What is the first thing you do when you try to reinstall OS

title: Business Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 months. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Phoenix, AZ) in Oct 2014
Interview Descriptions: This is a public/private University that has a public hiring process which can take a while to complete. The background and fingerprinting process may take up to 3 months to complete as well.
Interview Questions: Why do you feel you are the candidate for this position?

title: Teaching Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Arizona State University
Interview Descriptions: was hired in less than ten mins , because my thesis advisor needed a TA. All I had to do to get the TA was walk up to a professor and tell him my GPA and he gladly accepted it. Went a floor below to HR and got the TA !
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Grader Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1+ week. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Sept 2014
Interview Descriptions: I applied online and they asked me to come in for an interview about a week later. It was extremely simple. We just went over some fit questions and then looked at my transcript to see what classes I could grade for. They told me I was accepted when the interview was over.
Interview Questions: What would you do if you suspected a student of cheating?

title: Lab Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 3 days. I interviewed at Arizona State University
Interview Descriptions: I was recruited and cherry picked for the position. I was asked to submit an updated resume and for reference. They asked my salary requirement. I gave them a 10K range to pick from and was happy with the offer.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Technology Support Analyst Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Arizona State University
Interview Descriptions: Interviewed with the engineering college for a help desk position.  The interview was less conversational, and more about the interview (who looked very uncomfortable) going through a very long list of screening questions.
Interview Questions: How would you rate the amount of experience you have in Active Directory (on a scale from 1-10)?  No follow-up, just wanted a number.  Weird.

title: Tech Consultant At University Technology Office Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Aug 2014
Interview Descriptions: Online application. They will call you or email you if they want to set up a meeting. After that the interview is pretty simple. They will ask you what are your technical skills, can you fix computers or projectors. If you have similar experience in the past. How to resolve various technical problems related to computers and projectors.
Interview Questions: Details about various work scenarios and how to resolve them.

title: Undergraduate Research Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Aug 2014
Interview Descriptions: All email communications took several days, if not a full week to get a reply. The interviewer seemed more unprepared for the interview than I was. Office had an awkward air about it. Very uncomfortable interview process as a result.
Interview Questions: What would you like to get out of this opportunity?

title: Graduate Teaching Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1+ week. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Aug 2014
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was very standard. We were contacted about the position via email from WP Carey and were required to submit a resume and cover letter to the head of the department. There was an in-person interview with the department head and the supervising professor where we were asked about our experience at ASU, our teaching style, and why we were interested in being a TA.
Interview Questions: How would you handle a student who was having difficulty comprehending the material in class?

title: Grader Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Aug 2014
Interview Descriptions: I got a mail from the professor to meet him during his office hours. Interview depends on the professor. They test you on very basics knowledge in the  subject. Please go prepared for the interview.
Interview Questions:
* When did you take this course?
* Which textbook did you follow?
* Whats your knowledge?

title: Graduate Teaching Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Aug 2014
Interview Descriptions: A brief one to one interview. The professor asked a few questions regarding weekly availability. It was smooth as I had previously been a student in the class that I was offered t be a TA for.
Interview Questions: Would you be biased towards friends in the class I would be working as a TA for?

title: Research Technician Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University
Interview Descriptions: Applied online and received email and phone call a week later to do a phone interview. Phone interview focused on what the position would entail and my resume, research background, and interest in position. After phone interview, received email asking me to come in for a tour of facilities and do a panel interview. Interviewers were professional, easy-going, and very knowledgeable.
Interview Questions: No difficult questions - just questions about research background and abilities and any concerns about the job

title: Front Desk Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Mesa, AZ) in Jul 2014
Interview Descriptions: Phone interview, followed by an in-person group interview stage. Consisted of a panel of former and current professional and student staff members. Each would take turns asking the interviewee a question from the question bank and then would record the responses on a scale of 1-10 (10 being most favorable)
Interview Questions: When faced with a difficult situation you have not encountered before, how would you resolve the issue?

title: Associate International Educator Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Jul 2014
Interview Descriptions: Each member of the panel had a list of assigned questions to ask. Interview was "round-robin" style, one question, one response. No elaboration was needed for answers to questions that didn't require it.
Interview Questions: How would you handle it if a student came to you to negotiate a grade?

title: Project Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University in Jul 2014
Interview Descriptions: Fast paced organization, team and leadership. Interested in leadership examples and real-life experiences. 45 minute interview, cordial and conversational, getting to know one another's teamwork and leadership styles. Discussed organization and individual goals, challenges, future plans and day-to-day activities. Good communication all through the process.
Interview Questions: Tell us about your most difficult teamwork situation and how it was resolved.

title: Teaching Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Jul 2014
Interview Descriptions: None really It was pretty easy, they called me and I showed up, they asked about my experience and if I had experience I told them yes. I worked in the laboratory stock room. The job is pretty easy except for the wanna be supervisor.
Interview Questions: When could you start working

title: Customer Service Representative Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Jul 2014
Interview Descriptions: Positive, Friendly, Clarity in evaluation, Mostly tested communication and listening skills, ability to be trained and learn new DBMS, Two types of profiles: Customer Service and Tech Support; across On Phone assist and Chat assistance
Interview Questions: Have you ever been in a conflict resolution situation before?

title: Building Manager Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Arizona State University
Interview Descriptions: I heard about the job on the student careerlink site that ASU offers. I submitted my resume, transcript, and proof of enrollment. About a week later I received an email asking for an interview. The interview was with two current student employees, one the supervisor and the other a current building manager. I was then contact via email again a couple days later asking for another interview. This time I was interviewed by higher full-time staff and upper-management. They then called me and informed me that I had been accepted and would receive an email soon.
Interview Questions: When was a time that you had to overcome diversity or a difficulty.

title: Academic Success Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ)
Interview Descriptions: Process can take a long time from posting to hiring.  Different areas to things differently, but there is usually an initial screening of applications from the HR area, then they go to the supervisor, then the committee does interviews of top candidates.
Interview Questions: There are many "scenario" type of questions.

title: GPCC Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Jun 2014
Interview Descriptions: One Interview, one on one with supervisor. Apply online and got a call in 4 days. After interview got reply in 3 days. very friendly interview. interviewer was helpful and asked only behavioural questions.
Interview Questions: about yourself

title: Orientation Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Jun 2014
Interview Descriptions: First, I applied with my resume, details and references on the online Arizona State University job portal. Once the initial screening was done, I was informed that they needed to schedule an interview with me. After the personal interview with 2 interviewers, they informed me that I got the job and an offer letter was sent to me.
Interview Questions: They asked me to give them an example of how I show that I was a team player.

title: Walk Only Zone Ambassador Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Arizona State University in Jun 2014
Interview Descriptions: Nothing difficult. Please go through walk only zones website and you can answer any type of question. For me, it took 2 weeks to get a result, and 1 month to get a call from HR
Interview Questions: Just 4 questions. 1. Describe Customer Service? 2. Directions to certain buildings? 3. How would you react when somebody has an urgency and ask you to allow drive in the restricted zones?

title: Student Office Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in May 2014
Interview Descriptions: It was pretty straight forward interview. They call you to set up an in person interview. You go to their office and get interviewed by two supervisors. They ask you about your strengths and weaknesses, past jobs, etc.
Interview Questions: How would you act under pressure?

title: Graduate Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in May 2014
Interview Descriptions: One on One interview with project manager who is also a research scientist, expect technical questions as well as behavioral. This interview was for dragoon project at ASU under Dr. Kurt Van Lehn. it was an hour to hour and half long process with a simple one on one setting testing your technical skills as well as interest on this project
Interview Questions: Sql injection

title: Recruiting Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in May 2014
Interview Descriptions: It was very easy for me because I already volunteered with Recruiting. I stopped by the Director's office (in casual dress) and chatted with her because we both knew I already had the job. It was not stressful at all, and the management is very helpful. Vibe is usually casual, but if you are having a formal interview, you better dress professionally! At least business casual.
Interview Questions: What days can you work?

title: Enrollment Counselor Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 6 days. I interviewed at Arizona State University in May 2014
Interview Descriptions: I went to the main office which was sky song. I spoke with 2 managers. it was very cordial and we had great conversation..hey want to know you have good energy and a passion for higher education.
Interview Questions: really basic, my long term goals, where I want to be in a few years, my education.

title: University Tech Support Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in May 2014
Interview Descriptions: The Interview process was very smooth and they helped you be at ease. Quite friendly and precise. You are asked scenario based questions where you are put in a situation and asked your point of view.
Interview Questions: Have you faced a situation where the person in front of you had a bad temper and was disappointed with your service, how would you deal with the situation?

title: Math Tutor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in May 2014
Interview Descriptions: It was an easy and fast process.  I applied on-line.  I got the response in a week.  The interview was scheduled in couple weeks. I had 1 to 1 interview with couple of my future supervisors. All questions were behavioral. I got the position mostly because of my previous experience as math tutor at a community college.
Interview Questions:
1. Tell your 5 good qualities
2. Tell us your 1 bad quality
3. very unexpected question: why people climb mountains?

title: Peer Career Advisor Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at Arizona State University in May 2014
Interview Descriptions: They took long to call me for an interview but apart from that the process was easy. Had to create a presentation on myself and show it to them. I had only one interview and it was easy from there on.
Interview Questions: Basic questions such as: Tell me about yourself, strengths and weaknesses, questions about handling conflict.

title: Faculty Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Mesa, AZ) in May 2014
Interview Descriptions: I toured the Aviation Department at the Polytechnic Campus in May, just to see how they were set up. Later in August, out of the blue, the chair of the department contacted me and asked if I would be interested in teaching part-time for a couple of the labs. When I asked when we could schedule the interview, she said we already had...when I took the tour. Best interview I've ever had.
Interview Questions: How would I work with easily distracted or apathetic students?

title: Student Worker IV Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University
Interview Descriptions: Took about two week for the whole hiring process. I applied through portal and got an interview opportunity, it was a one to one interview with just basic situation based questions, strengths and weakness.  The next day after the interview I got an email and they offered me a job.
Interview Questions: Just basic HR questions.

title: Research Analyst Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University in Apr 2014
Interview Descriptions: Apply online through ASU website. Find position through the online portal.  Send resume and cover letter to HR, phone call, scheduled interview, interview, wait to hear back from HR.
Interview Questions: What is your experience?

title: Operations Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Scottsdale, AZ) in Mar 2014
Interview Descriptions: Once you applied for the job on the portal your profile gets screened by HR. I got a call in about 10 days. I had an onsite interview at skysong after which I heard back in a week.
Interview Questions: What makes you think that you can be a valuable employee to the team?

title: Tutor Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Arizona State University
Interview Descriptions: online application, interview and job!!
Interview Questions: willing to continue during exams,

title: Graduate Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at Arizona State University in Feb 2014
Interview Descriptions: Sent application with essay. Had  a phone interview. In person interview with professor 2 weeks later. Tour of facility and laboratory.  Second interview with professors as we talked about research. Then wait while they interview other candidates. Finally, got an email with offer.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Teaching Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Feb 2014
Interview Descriptions: For simple process. You get accepted to the university by submitting relevant application material (i.e. GRE, PGRE, Personal Statement) and do well in classes. In essence, the interview process is an assessment of your capability.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Purchasing Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Feb 2014
Interview Descriptions: one in person interview with a panel of senior employees and managers. Was very relaxed environment and employees made you feel at ease. Everyone was very friendly and tried to make the process more of a conversation rather than an interview.
Interview Questions: What is your previous work experience and how can it be applied here?

title: Graduate Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 months. I interviewed at Arizona State University
Interview Descriptions: I applied online as many advanced educated Chinese back in China. There is no interview at all. We submitted a package of material including CV, personal statement, transcripts, certificate, GRE score report, TOEFL score report, etc.
Interview Questions: No questions asked, just waiting waiting and waiting. The difficulty is ASU is not as I expected from a US research university.

title: Student Office Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Arizona State University
Interview Descriptions: very predictable; do not worry about.....why left last job, strengths, weakness all that other crap
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Graphic Designer Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ)
Interview Descriptions: Applied on-line about a week later I got a call asking to schedule and interview, The interview lasted about a hour and a half. They asked many questions about my overall design process and was given scenarios and hypothetical events to design flyers and marketing materials for on the spot.
Interview Questions: Draw us a flyer for a carnival for the senior class?

title: Assistant Director of Recruitment and Admissions Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Jan 2014
Interview Descriptions: About a 2-3 hour process, had a phone screening which was about 30 minutes, invited back to assess skills using the computer and their website, then the director and HR interviewed me and then I went to meet the team I would be working with and gave them a 3 minute presentation.
Interview Questions: What was a strength and weakness my manager put on my last yearly review?

title: Tutor Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Phoenix, AZ) in Jan 2014
Interview Descriptions: Brief one on one interview.  It was pretty casual and laid back. There was only one interview and was completed in roughly and hour.  The offer was made later that day.
Interview Questions: What is your method to solving problems?

title: Bicycle Mechanic Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 3 days. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Jan 2014
Interview Descriptions: Fairly straightforward, you had to either know what you were doing or be very dedicated to learning.  I applied first online, then went in to talk to the manager.  At the time I didn't know a ton about bike mechanics, but I knew enough to be useful which is what they were looking for.  Definitely express a willingness to learn as you go.
Interview Questions: What does ____ tool do?

title: 911 Dispatcher Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Arizona State University in Jan 2014
Interview Descriptions: Like all state police department positions the interview process takes months and you must jump thru many hoops to be hired.  You will be required to take a polygraph test, drug test, psych and medical examination among other things.
Interview Questions: How do you handle stressful situations

title: Student Worker III Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Jan 2014
Interview Descriptions: I walked through my design portfolio and had a very laid back interview regarding my strengths and weaknesses. We talked about the different computer programs that I knew how to use. He was mostly concerned with my actual abilities, and not how sociable I was.
Interview Questions: Are you proficient in Adobe Suites?

title: Graduate Research Assistant Volunteer Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Jan 2014
Interview Descriptions: The professor will ask you why you want to do this job and what are your good at. Then you two will discuss whether you need the pay. If the professor thinks you are good, he will explain the project to you and tell you what you need to do.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to join our group?

title: Student Worker III Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Scottsdale, AZ) in Jan 2014
Interview Descriptions: Pretty straightforward. You go into Skysong, they take you into a meeting you, interviewer/hiring manager asks you questions. Questions are pretty simple, and very much team-oriented. Hiring process was way too long. Did not think I initially got the job, was called 30 days later saying I did. They do perform reference checks after the interview.
Interview Questions: What is your GPA?

title: Administrative Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Arizona State University (Tempe, AZ) in Dec 2013
Interview Descriptions: All applicants must apply online. Keywords in your resume (that match the posting) are what will flag your application for consideration to HR. The interview will consist of 10 questions that each interviewer will rotate asking and taking notes of your answers. They are panel interviews with anywhere from 2 to 4 people sitting in. After an initial interview a second interview with the Director 1:1 was required.
